central_thesis: The Tarot, specifically the Major Arcana, represents a fundamental map of the human psyche and the process of spiritual unfoldment, offering practical tools for self-understanding, discrimination, and the integration of conscious, subconscious, and superconscious faculties for the attainment of holistic well-being and realization.

structure_content.summary: This lesson delves into the esoteric significance of The Lovers (Key 6) in the Tarot. It presents the card as a symbol of enlightenment, the differentiation of the One Force into pairs of opposites, and the process of discrimination. The imagery of Raphael, the angel, is dissected, linking its colors and attributes to Mercury, Mars, and Venus, symbolizing reason, action, and imagination. The text explains the angel as superconsciousness, the man as self-consciousness, and the woman as subconsciousness, all interacting under the divine guidance of the angel. The lesson emphasizes that true healing and attainment come through the integration of these faculties and contact with the Self. The mountain symbolizes attainment, the tree represents knowledge and the senses, and the serpent symbolizes Kundalini or the power of vibration that can lead to both delusion and liberation. The practical application focuses on the need for right discrimination, achieved through careful observation, intuition, and the conscious correction of erroneous subconscious interpretations. The text introduces a practical formula for addressing subconsciousness to align it with superconscious wisdom, promoting strength and orderly manifestation. It also advises daily practice of reviewing the Tarot keys studied as representations of the real self, and considering personal aspirations in relation to others and the surrounding circumstances.

key_concepts.definition: The goal of practical occult work, represented by the golden Sun in Key 6, signifying a state of ultimate understanding and awareness.
The One Force differentiating into dualistic aspects, which must be harmonized through discrimination. The Lovers card symbolizes this differentiation and the potential for union.

The faculty of discerning correctly, achieved through a blend of reason, imagination, intuition, and careful observation. It is presented as the key to control and understanding, enabling the correct classification of experiences and leading to intuitive insights.
Represented by the man in Key 6, this is the faculty that observes, reasons, and makes interpretations. It is responsible for both erroneous interpretations and their correction.

Represented by the woman in Key 6, this faculty is the seat of instincts, emotions, and subconscious programming. It is amenable to suggestion and acts as a reflection of conscious thought and higher intelligence.

Represented by the angel Raphael, this is the divine, higher intelligence that guides and illuminates. It is the source of ultimate wisdom and healing, accessed through developed discrimination and self-awareness.

The coiled serpent around the tree symbolizes the vital, vibrational force. Initially, it can lead to temptation and delusion, but when understood and correctly applied, it can lead to liberation and overcoming error.
The ultimate Unity, the source of all existence. Right discrimination leads to the recognition of the ALL and true healing through contact with the Self.
The subconscious mind produces mental imagery based on the 'mental seeds' or premises planted by self-conscious thought. Creating clear, positive mental images is crucial for manifestation.

practical_system.description: The practical system centers on the concept of 'right discrimination' as the key to harmonizing the levels of human consciousness (self-consciousness, subconsciousness, and superconsciousness) and achieving holistic well-being. The core practice involves a directed affirmation or 'magical formula' addressed to the subconsciousness, instructing it to release erroneous interpretations, accept guidance from superconsciousness, and manifest divine order, strength, and ability. This is supported by daily study of the lesson, contemplation of Tarot imagery as representations of the 'real self,' and mindful consideration of personal aspirations in relation to others and circumstances. The underlying principle is that by consciously directing the subconscious mind with accurate premises derived from superconscious wisdom, one can achieve inner and outer transformation.
tools: The Tarot deck (specifically the Major Arcana, as represented by Key 6).
Affirmations and spoken words (a personalized 'magical formula').
Mindful observation of personal thoughts, feelings, and external circumstances.
rituals: Daily reading and contemplation of the lesson.
Daily meditation on the imagery of the Tarot keys studied, recognizing them as aspects of the real self.
Daily recitation of a personalized affirmation directed to subconsciousness, to be spoken nightly before sleep, and during moments of mental/emotional tension.

relevant_quotes.text: Thus are blended in the angel's hair the colors of the planets which rule Aries, Taurus and Gemini. The suggestion is that in discrimination we make use of reason (red, Aries, Emperor), and imagination and intuition (green, Venus, Empress and Hierophant), in order to make correct classifications.

The angel is superconsciousness. He therefore rests on a cloud to indicate that the powers and activities of superconsciousness are partly hidden from us because we have not yet developed, as we shall in due season, the organic centers in our brains through which superconsciousness is realized.

The angel's name, Raphael, means â€œGod is the healer". This agrees with the Egyptian doctrine that Thoth (Mercury) is the god of medicine. It refers also to the idea that right discrimination leads to the recognition of the Unity which is the ALL. The true healing is the attainment of inner and outer wholeness through contact with the Self.

The man looks at the woman, but the woman looks upward toward the angel. Whatever self-consciousness observes directly is the activity of subconsciousness. Yet subconsciousness, brought under the influence of right discrimination, may be made to reflect the activity of super-consciousness, the angel in this Key.

All our miseries and limitations result from subconscious developments of erroneous interpretations of our experience. Self-consciousness makes these erroneous interpretations. Self-consciousness must also correct them. For subconsciousness has no power of inductive reasoning, and its production of mental imagery is determined by the premises, or mental seeds, planted by our self-conscious thinking.

The serpent coiled round the tree is the serpent-power, Kundalini, of the yogis. It is also the serpent of temptation Nachash, whose name has the numeral value, 358, as the name Messiah, the Anointed, which is translated Christos in Greek, and Christ in English. What is meant is that the serpent-power of vibration is the force which, at first, leads us into temptation through delusion; and then delivers us from evil when we know how to apply it to overcome error.

Discrimination requires careful observation of what goes on in one's environment, and, most of all, careful survey of one's employment of time. Yet the most careful collection and arrangement of data and of statistics will profit you nothing unless you develop some measure of intuition.

Thus Key 6 intimates clearly that both physical sight and mental vision are at work in discrimination. Behind the whole scene is the sun, intimating that light, the basis of physical sight, is the force at work throughout what is pictured by this Key. Metaphysically, this means that all our power of discrimination is derived from the light of the universal superconsciousness.
Hence your practical work for this week should be addressed to considering your personal aspirations and desires in relation to the other persons with whom your life is most intimately connected.

Henceforth, you are free from the influence of any misinterpretations of experience resulting from errors in my self-conscious reasoning. You will refuse to accept, or act upon, such misinterpretations. Instead, you will be guided by the influx of superconscious life and wisdom. "Under this influence, you will set my body in perfect order. Through this wisdom, you will guide me aright in all my affairs. By the reflection of this boundless power, you will give me strength, ability and persistence to accomplish all I have to do."

critical_analysis.relevance: This text is highly relevant to practitioners of Western Esotericism, particularly those following the teachings of the School of Spiritual Science or the Builders of the Adytum (BOTA), founded by the author. It offers a deeply psychological and spiritual interpretation of the Tarot, aligning it with Hermetic principles and Gnostic ideas of consciousness. The emphasis on discrimination, the interplay of conscious, subconscious, and superconscious, and the practical application through meditation and affirmation provide a framework for personal transformation applicable to those seeking inner development and occult understanding.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary audience is students and practitioners of Tarot and esoteric philosophy, especially those interested in the psychological and spiritual dimensions of the Tarot as taught by Paul Foster Case and his lineage. It is also relevant for individuals interested in consciousness studies, meditation, and self-improvement through occult principles.
